series.short: "Income Tax Rates and Allowances in the UK for 2021-22"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2021 sets the income tax rates for the tax year 2021-22.
* Simplified point 2: The basic rate of income tax is 20%, the higher rate is 40%, and the additional rate is 45%.
* Simplified point 3: The default and savings rates of income tax are the same as the basic, higher, and additional rates.
* Simplified point 4: The starting rate limit for savings is £5,000, and the personal allowance is £12,570 for the tax years 2022-23, 2023-24, 2024-25, and 2025-26.
* Simplified point 5: The basic rate limit and personal allowance will increase each year by the Consumer Prices Index (CPI) for the tax years 2022-23, 2023-24, 2024-25, and 2025-26.

series.short: "Corporation Tax Rates for Financial Years 2022-2023: Main Rate and Small Profits Rate"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: Corporation tax is charged for the financial years 2022 and 2023 at a main rate of 19% for 2022 and 25% for 2023.
* Simplified point 2: For the financial year 2023, a small profits rate of 19% will be charged on profits that are not ring fence profits, with marginal relief given by reference to the standard marginal relief fraction of 3/200ths.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation makes amendments to Chapter 3A of Part 8 of CTA2010 (corporation tax rates on ring fence profits) and other consequential amendments to provision made by the Corporation Tax Acts.

series.short: "Increased Diverted Profits Tax Rate Under Finance Act 2021"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2021 increases the rate of diverted profits tax from 25% to 31%.
* Simplified point 2: The increase in the rate applies to accounting periods beginning on or after April 1, 2023, and the legislation provides rules for apportioning the tax chargeable on a company with a straddling period (i.e., one that spans both before and after April 1, 2023).

series.short: "UK Government's Super-Deductions for Business Investments"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is providing super-deductions for companies that invest in qualifying plant and machinery.
* Simplified point 2: Companies can claim a 130% first-year allowance on expenditure incurred on plant and machinery that is unused and not second-hand, and a 50% first-year allowance on expenditure incurred on special rate expenditure.
* Simplified point 3: The super-deductions are available for expenditure incurred on or after 1 April 2021 but before 1 April 2023, and are only available to companies within the charge to corporation tax.
* Simplified point 4: The super-deductions are not available for expenditure on the provision of plant or machinery for use wholly or partly for the purposes of a ring fence trade.
* Simplified point 5: The super-deductions are not available for expenditure on the provision of plant or machinery for leasing.
* Simplified point 6: The super-deductions are subject to certain exclusions and restrictions, such as the general exclusions in section 46(2) of CAA 2001 and the excluded lease of background plant or machinery for a building.
* Simplified point 7: The super-deductions are subject to certain conditions and requirements, such as the expenditure being incurred under a contract and the plant or machinery being unused and not second-hand.

series.short: "Finance Act 2021 Provisions for Super-Deductions and SR Allowances"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2021 provides additional provisions for super-deductions and SR allowances, which are special tax deductions for businesses that invest in certain types of assets.
* Simplified point 2: The section modifies the percentage that would otherwise apply to super-deduction expenditure incurred in a chargeable period that ends on or after April 1, 2023, and provides provisions for the disposal of plant or machinery in respect of which a super-deduction was made.
* Simplified point 3: The section also contains provisions about counteracting tax advantages in connection with super-deductions and SR allowances, and has effect as if it were contained in Chapter 5 of Part 2 of CAA 2001.
* Simplified point 4: The section defines certain terms used in the provisions, including "super-deduction expenditure", "SR allowance expenditure", and "additional VAT liability".

series.short: "Reduced Super-Deduction for Pre-April 2023 Expenditure"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This extract of the legislation allows for a reduced super-deduction for certain expenditure incurred by a person in a chargeable period that ends on or after April 1, 2023.
* Simplified point 2: The reduced super-deduction is determined by a percentage that is based on the number of days in the relevant period before April 1, 2023, and the total number of days in that period.
* Simplified point 3: The reduced super-deduction is only available if the person becomes entitled to the super-deduction as a result of section 236(2) of the Finance Act 2021.
* Simplified point 4: The reduced super-deduction is only available for certain expenditure incurred before April 1, 2023, and not for expenditure incurred after that date.
* Simplified point 5: The reduced super-deduction is a percentage of the super-deduction expenditure, and the percentage is determined by the number of days in the relevant period before April 1, 2023, and the total number of days in that period.

series.short: "Finance Act 2021 Balancing Charges for Disposals of Assets"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2021 deals with the balancing charges for disposals of assets where super-deductions were made.
* Simplified point 2: When a person disposes of an asset that was subject to a super-deduction, they may be liable for a balancing charge.
* Simplified point 3: The amount of the balancing charge is based on the amount of super-deduction expenditure incurred in respect of the asset and the disposal value of the asset.
* Simplified point 4: The relevant proportion of the disposal value is determined by dividing the amount of relevant super-deduction expenditure by the total relevant expenditure in relation to the asset.
* Simplified point 5: The balancing charge is reduced by the relevant proportion of the disposal value of the asset.
* Simplified point 6: This section applies to disposals occurring on or after 1 April 2021.

series.short: "Finance Act 2021 Disposal Asset Balancing Charges"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2021 deals with the balancing charges for disposals of assets where SR allowance was made.
* Simplified point 2: The person who incurred SR allowance expenditure is liable to a balancing charge for the chargeable period in which the disposal event occurs, and the amount of the charge is based on the disposal value of the asset.
* Simplified point 3: The relevant proportion of the disposal value is determined by dividing the amount of relevant SR allowance expenditure by the total relevant expenditure in relation to the asset.
* Simplified point 4: The total relevant expenditure includes relevant SR allowance expenditure, any expenditure in respect of which any other first-year allowance was made, and any expenditure that is not relevant SR allowance expenditure that was allocated to a pool for any chargeable period.
* Simplified point 5: The TDR for the pool to which the SR allowance expenditure was allocated is reduced by the amount of the balancing charge.
* Simplified point 6: This section does not apply to disposals of ships.
* Simplified point 7: This section comes into effect on or after April 1, 2021.

series.short: "Tax Loophole Closure: Counteracting Contrived Arrangements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2021 aims to counteract any tax advantages obtained through contrived or abnormal arrangements.
* Simplified point 2: The section applies to any arrangements entered into on or after March 3, 2021, and allows for adjustments to be made to tax claims through assessments, modifications, amendments, or disallowances.
* Simplified point 3: The term "arrangements" includes any agreements, understandings, schemes, transactions, or series of transactions, whether legally enforceable or not.
* Simplified point 4: The section uses the term "tax advantage" as defined in section 577(4) of the Corporation Tax Act 2001.
* Simplified point 5: The section is aimed at preventing the exploitation of shortcomings in the Corporation Tax Act 2001, particularly in relation to the super-deduction and the SR allowance.

series.short: "UK Finance Act 2021 Modifications for Coronavirus-Related Leases"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The text delimited by triple backticks is an extract of clauses from a piece of UK Legislation, specifically Finance Act 2021, which deals with capital allowances and leases.
* Simplified point 2: The extract modifies existing provisions related to plant and machinery leases, specifically for reasons related to coronavirus. It introduces a new section 70YCA, which extends the term of lease for reasons related to coronavirus, and makes elections under that section irrevocable.
* Simplified point 3: The modifications apply to leases incurred on or after 1 January 2020, and the Treasury may by regulations substitute for the second date for the time being specified in subsection (2)(a) such other date as they consider appropriate.
* Simplified point 4: The text also includes provisions related to elections under section 70YCA, which must be made by notice to an officer of Revenue and Customs, and includes information specified by an officer of Revenue and Customs.
* Simplified point 5: The provisions do not apply to an election under section 70YCA, and references in this section to a tax return, in the case of an election for the purposes of a trade, profession or business carried on by persons in partnership, are to be read, in relation to those persons, as references to a return under section 12AA of TMA 1970 (partnership returns).

series.short: "Business Tax Relief Measures Extended"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The temporary extension of periods to which trade losses may be carried back.
* Simplified point 2: The extension of social investment tax relief for further two years.

This means that businesses can claim relief on past losses for a longer period of time. series.short: "UK Tax Law Changes Target Misused Intermediaries for Fairness"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is making changes to the tax laws regarding workers' services provided through intermediaries, specifically targeting the misuse of intermediaries to avoid paying taxes.

* Simplified point 2: The changes include expanding the definition of "worker" to include those with a material interest in the intermediary, and introducing a new chain payment rule to prevent the avoidance of taxes.

* Simplified point 3: The legislation also includes new anti-avoidance measures to prevent the use of fraudulent information and to recover payments made to workers through intermediaries.

* Simplified point 4: The amendments made by this section have effect in relation to deemed direct payments treated as made on or after 6 April 2021.

In summary, the UK government is strengthening the tax laws regarding workers' services provided through intermediaries to prevent tax avoidance and ensure fairness in the tax system.

series.short: UK Finance Act 2021 Amends Income Tax Rules for Termination Payments
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK Finance Act 2021 amends the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003 (ITEPA) to change the way certain termination payments are taxed.
* Simplified point 2: The amendments apply to general earnings that are subject to UK income tax and are paid in connection with a termination of employment on or after April 6, 2021.
* Simplified point 3: The changes affect the calculation of taxable earnings for the year when an employee is not resident in the UK, and introduce a new percentage-based calculation for certain termination payments.
* Simplified point 4: The amendments also make changes to the definition of "post-employment notice pay" and introduce a new formula for calculating the amount of pay that is subject to tax.
* Simplified point 5: The changes are intended to ensure that termination payments are taxed fairly and consistently, and to prevent employers from avoiding tax on certain types of payments.

series.short: "Tax Amendments for Zero-Emissions Vans in UK"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This legislation amends the Finance Act 2021 to change the cash equivalent benefit of a zero-emissions van for tax years 2021-22 and later.
* Simplified point 2: The amendment reduces the cash equivalent benefit to nil if the van cannot emit CO2 in any circumstances and is driven in tax years 2021-22 and later.
* Simplified point 3: The amendment also removes paragraph (g) of subsection (1C) of section 155 of ITEPA 2003.
* Simplified point 4: The amendment adds a new paragraph (aa) to subsection (1B) of section 155 of ITEPA 2003, which provides a cash equivalent benefit for zero-emissions vans in tax years 2021-22 and later.
* Simplified point 5: The amendment also updates the reference to "2021-22" in subsection (1B) to "2020-21" to reflect the previous tax year.

series.short: "UK Finance Act Modifications Allow Employees to Miss Work Due to Coronavirus Without Losing EMI Status."
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2021 modifies the Enterprise Management Incentives (EMI) scheme to allow employees to not work for reasons connected to coronavirus disease, without losing their EMI status.
* Simplified point 2: The modification applies to the period starting from March 19, 2020, and ending on April 5, 2022.
* Simplified point 3: The modification affects paragraphs 26 and 27 of Schedule 5 to the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003, and section 535 of the same Act.
* Simplified point 4: The modification allows for the disregard of not working due to coronavirus disease when determining the commitment of working time for EMI purposes.
* Simplified point 5: The modification ensures that the meaning of "working time" includes time not worked due to coronavirus disease.

series.short: "Employer Cycle Provide Safety Equipment Before Dec 21, 2020 Considered Commuting"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The legislation allows for cycles and cyclist's safety equipment provided to employees before December 21, 2020, to be considered as meeting the condition for commuting, etc.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation applies to cycles and safety equipment provided to employees starting from March 16, 2020, and ending on April 5, 2022.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation defines "cycle" and "cyclist" as per section 244 of ITEPA 2003.

series.short: "COVID-19 Test Exemptions: Income Tax Relief for Employees"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The section exempts employees from paying income tax on coronavirus tests and related costs.
* Simplified point 2: The exemption applies to tests that detect the presence of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19.
* Simplified point 3: The exemption is effective for the tax years 2020-21 and 2021-22, and can be extended to subsequent tax years through regulations made by the Treasury.
* Simplified point 4: The section supersedes previous regulations (Income Tax (Exemption of Minor Benefits) (Coronavirus) Regulations 2020) that provided similar relief.

series.short: "Employees Given Option for Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay Updates"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This legislation amends the Finance Act 2017 to include statutory parental bereavement pay as an optional remuneration arrangement.
* Simplified point 2: The amendment allows for the inclusion of statutory parental bereavement pay in the same category as statutory shared parental pay, making it an optional remuneration arrangement.
* Simplified point 3: The amendment ensures that the Schedule has effect and is deemed to have always had effect with the amendment made by subsection (1).

In simpler terms, this legislation updates the Finance Act 2017 to include statutory parental bereavement pay as an optional remuneration arrangement, allowing employees to choose to receive this type of pay in addition to statutory shared parental pay. The amendment ensures that the Schedule has effect and is deemed to have always had effect with the amendment made by subsection (1).

series.short: "Pension Lifetime Allowance Freeze Extended Until 2026"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The standard lifetime allowance for pensions is frozen at £1,073,100 for the tax years 2021-22 to 2025-26.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation makes amendments to Part 4 of the Finance Act 2004 relating to collective money purchase benefits.

series.short: "Amendments to Construction Industry Scheme (CIS): Improved Taxation for Contractors and Subcontractors"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract from the Finance Act 2021 relates to the Construction Industry Scheme (CIS) and amends Chapter 3 of Part 3 of the Finance Act 2004.
* Simplified point 2: The Schedule makes provisions for contractors, deductions on account of tax from contract payments, the treatment of sums deducted, and penalties related to the CIS.

* Simplified point 4: The amendments in the Schedule aim to ensure that contractors deduct the correct amount of tax from payments made to subcontractors and that the sums deducted are treated correctly for tax purposes.
* Simplified point 5: The extract also includes provisions for penalties for non-compliance with the CIS, which serves as an incentive for contractors and subcontractors to follow the correct procedures.

series.short: "UK Government's Financial Support for Businesses Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic: Taxation Provisions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is providing financial support to businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic through various schemes, including the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme and the Self-Employment Income Support Scheme.
* Simplified point 2: The Finance Act 2021 is amending the taxation of these support payments to ensure that they are not subject to income tax, and to provide for the deduction of expenses incurred in discharging liabilities to public authorities.
* Simplified point 3: The Act is also providing for the self-employment income support scheme payments to be treated as receipts of the tax year 2020-21, and for the charge if a person is not entitled to a coronavirus support payment.
* Simplified point 4: The amendments made by the Finance Act 2021 have effect in relation to coronavirus support payments received on or after 6 April 2021, and the section 106 of the Finance Act 2020 is modified to include provision about the self-employment income support scheme.
* Simplified point 5: The section 106 of the Finance Act 2020 is also modified to include provision modifying the charge to income tax where a person is not entitled to a coronavirus support payment, and the deduction where business rates etc repaid.

series.short: Repeal of Interest and Royalties Directive Provisions and New Exemption for Payments to Victims of Modern Slavery
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The section repeals provisions related to the Interest and Royalties Directive, which exempted certain interest and royalty payments from income tax.
* Simplified point 2: The repeal of these provisions means that payments made on or after June 1, 2021, and payments made in disqualifying circumstances on or after March 3, 2021, but before June 1, 2021, will no longer be exempt from income tax.
* Simplified point 3: The section also makes amendments to other provisions in the Income Tax Acts to reflect the repeal of the Interest and Royalties Directive provisions.
* Simplified point 4: The section introduces a new exemption for payments made to victims of modern slavery, subject to certain conditions.
* Simplified point 5: The section defines "public authority" and "the Trafficking Convention" for the purposes of the new exemption.
* Simplified point 6: The section has effect in relation to qualifying payments received on or after April 1, 2009.

series.short: "Finance Act 2021 Amends Corporate Tax Laws in Minor Ways"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2021 makes minor amendments to existing laws related to corporation tax, including changes to the way Real Estate Investment Trusts are taxed and the treatment of interest restrictions.

* Simplified point 4: The section also includes provisions for relief for losses and other amounts, as well as changes to the way hybrid and other mismatches are taxed.

series.short: "Capital Gains Tax Changes in UK Budget 2021-22: Annual Exempt Amount Unchanged but Stricter Rules for Foreign-Controlled Companies"
series.text:

series.short: "Tax on Plastic Packaging Components in the UK"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2021 imposes a tax on plastic packaging components produced or imported into the UK.
* Simplified point 2: The tax is charged at a rate of £200 per metric tonne and is payable by reference to accounting periods determined by regulations.
* Simplified point 3: The tax applies to plastic packaging components of a single specification and the amount charged on part of a tonne is proportionately reduced.
* Simplified point 4: The tax is payable by the person who produces or imports the plastic packaging components, depending on the circumstances.
* Simplified point 5: The tax is subject to certain exemptions, as set out in section 52 of the Finance Act 2021.

series.short: The Finance Act 2021: Plastic Packaging Components and Recycling Requirements
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2021 defines chargeable plastic packaging components and the criteria for determining whether a plastic packaging component is chargeable or not.
* Simplified point 2: A plastic packaging component is considered chargeable if it contains less than 30% recycled plastic by weight and has undergone a substantial modification.
* Simplified point 3: The definition of "plastic packaging component" includes any product designed for use in the containment, protection, handling, delivery, or presentation of goods, regardless of why it is produced or imported.
* Simplified point 4: The meaning of "plastic" and "recycled plastic" is defined in the legislation, and plastic is not considered recycled plastic unless it is shown to be so.
* Simplified point 5: The legislation also covers the time of importation of chargeable plastic packaging components into the UK.

series.short: "UK Plastic Packaging Tax Deferral for Export: Conditions and Exemptions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is allowing a deferral of plastic packaging tax for components intended for export, as long as certain conditions are met.
* Simplified point 2: The direct export condition must be met, which means that the component must be exported from the UK within a certain period of time, and the person liable for the tax must have intended to export the component from the beginning.
* Simplified point 3: If the Commissioners are not satisfied of any matter within subsection (2) in relation to a component, they may notify the liable person that the direct export condition is no longer met, and the tax liability will be cancelled or taken never to have been deferred.
* Simplified point 4: The deferral period for plastic packaging components is 12 months, starting from the day the component is produced or imported.
* Simplified point 5: Certain plastic packaging components are exempt from plastic packaging tax, such as transport packaging or tertiary packaging within the meaning of regulation 3(2)(c) of the Packaging (Essential Requirements) Regulations 2015, or road, rail, ship, and air containers.
* Simplified point 6: The Treasury may make regulations creating further exemptions from plastic packaging tax.
* Simplified point 7: The Commissioners may make regulations providing for tax credits in cases where a person has become liable to pay plastic packaging tax on a prescribed component that is later exported or converted into a different packaging component.

series.short: "Plastic Packaging Tax Register Established and Maintained by Commissioners"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The register of plastic packaging tax is established and maintained by the Commissioners.
* Simplified point 2: The register contains information such as names of registered persons, sites where they carry on business, and registration numbers.
* Simplified point 3: Information from the register can be published by the Commissioners, subject to certain conditions and restrictions.
* Simplified point 4: Liability to register is determined by the amount of finished plastic packaging components produced or imported, and notification of liability must be made within a certain timeframe.
* Simplified point 5: Registrations can be cancelled if the person no longer meets the liability condition, and the Commissioners may decline to cancel a registration if they believe the person will become liable again within a certain period.
* Simplified point 6: The register can be corrected by the Commissioners through regulations.

series.short: "Plastic Packaging Tax Liability Notices: Joint and Several Responsibility"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract discusses the provision of notices that can impose secondary liability or joint and several liability on individuals or entities in cases where another person has failed to pay plastic packaging tax.
* Simplified point 2: The notices can be issued in respect of an amount of plastic packaging tax for a period of time in the future, and can make one person jointly and severally liable with another person for that liability.
* Simplified point 3: The provision is made under Schedule 9 of the Finance Act 2021.

series.short: "Plastic Packaging Tax Regulations: Measurement, Record Keeping, and Security Requirements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Commissioners may make regulations to determine how weight is measured for plastic packaging components.
* Simplified point 2: The regulations may include provisions for the measurement of weight, the time period for which weight is measured, how weight is evidenced, and agreements between the Commissioners and individuals about how weight is measured or evidenced.
* Simplified point 3: The Commissioners may make their own assessment or best judgment of weight in relation to plastic packaging components and substitute that assessment or judgment for the assessment or judgment of any other person.
* Simplified point 4: The Commissioners may inspect or weigh plastic packaging components or samples.
* Simplified point 5: The regulations may provide for the payment, collection, and recovery of amounts for the purposes of plastic packaging tax, including provisions for determining accounting periods, keeping accounts, making returns, and correcting errors.
* Simplified point 6: The Commissioners may require persons to keep records for purposes connected with plastic packaging tax, and may direct a person to keep such records as are specified in the direction.
* Simplified point 7: The Commissioners may prescribe circumstances in which a person who is liable to be registered under section 55 may be required to give security for the payment of any plastic packaging tax due or which may become due.
* Simplified point 8: The Commissioners may make provision in relation to a business carried on by a partnership or by another unincorporated body, specifying by what person anything required by or under this Part to be done by a person is to be done.
* Simplified point 9: Anything required to be given to a person by or under a provision of this Part may be given by sending it to the person or their representative by post, addressed to that person’s last known address.

series.short: "Plastic Packaging Tax Legislation Requirements for Businesses"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The legislation requires businesses that supply plastic packaging components to include a statement of the amount of plastic packaging tax on the invoice to their customers.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation applies to businesses that supply plastic packaging components, regardless of whether they are supplying the components on their own or as part of other goods.
* Simplified point 3: The PPT statement must contain particulars prescribed by the Commissioners in regulations.
* Simplified point 4: The definition of "business customer" includes persons who are supplied with plastic packaging components in the course of carrying out a business.

series.short: "UK Tax Representation Requirements for Non-Resident Taxpayers"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government can require non-resident taxpayers to appoint a tax representative to act on their behalf for tax purposes.
* Simplified point 2: The tax representative is responsible for ensuring the non-resident taxpayer's compliance with tax obligations and liabilities, and is personally liable for any failures to do so.
* Simplified point 3: The tax representative must be approved by the UK government and can act on behalf of the non-resident taxpayer through an agent.
* Simplified point 4: The tax representative is not liable for tax registration, but the UK government can require the registration of their names against the names of the non-resident taxpayers they represent.
* Simplified point 5: The tax representative is not guilty of an offence except in cases where they consented to or connived in the commission of the offence by the non-resident taxpayer, or if the commission of the offence is attributable to neglect on the part of the tax representative.
* Simplified point 6: The definition of a non-resident taxpayer is provided, and includes individuals who have an established place of business or a usual place of residence in the UK, or who are firms or unincorporated bodies with at least one partner or member with a usual place of residence in the UK.

series.short: "Adjusting Contracts for Plastic Packaging Components: Tax Implications"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract of the legislation allows for adjustments to be made to contracts for the supply of chargeable plastic packaging components, taking into account any tax chargeable on the components.
* Simplified point 2: The extract of the legislation requires the party supplying the plastic packaging component to adjust the contract to reflect any changes in tax chargeable on the component, and to provide information about any conversions of the component into a different chargeable plastic packaging component.
* Simplified point 3: The extract of the legislation applies to contracts for the supply of chargeable plastic packaging components, and does not take into account the timing of the contract or other matters that may be covered in the contract.

series.short: "Plastic Packaging Tax Liability for Group Companies"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This extract of the legislation outlines the rules for when a group of companies is liable to pay plastic packaging tax.
* Simplified point 2: The representative member of the group is treated as if it were liable to pay the amount instead of the other members of the group.
* Simplified point 3: All members of the group are jointly and severally liable for the amount due from the representative member.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation provides for applications by two or more bodies corporate to be treated as members of the same group for the purposes of this Part.

In simpler terms, this extract of the legislation explains how a group of companies is responsible for paying plastic packaging tax. The representative member of the group is considered responsible for the tax, and all members of the group are jointly and severally liable for the amount due. The legislation also allows for applications to be made to be treated as members of the same group for the purposes of this Part.

series.short: "Preventing Artificial Separation in Plastic Packaging Taxation"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2021 aims to prevent artificial separation of business activities to avoid plastic packaging tax.
* Simplified point 2: The Commissioners can make directions to name persons who are producing or importing plastic packaging components, if their activities are artificially separated from other connected persons.
* Simplified point 3: The direction can specify a description of business and add names of persons to those already named, with effect from a certain date.
* Simplified point 4: Persons named in the direction cease to be liable to be registered under this Part with effect from the later of two dates.
* Simplified point 5: A direction under this section must be given to each person named in it.

series.short: "New Plastic Packaging Tax in the UK: Joint & Several Liability for Constituent Members"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2021 introduces a new tax on plastic packaging components in the UK.
* Simplified point 2: The tax is payable by a single taxable person, who is treated as a partnership carrying on the business of the taxable person.
* Simplified point 3: The constituent members of the partnership are jointly and severally liable for the plastic packaging tax due from the taxable person.
* Simplified point 4: The Commissioners have the power to give directions under section 72 of the Act, which can affect the status of the constituent members and their liability for the tax.
* Simplified point 5: The Act also provides for the registration of the taxable person and the requirement for the constituent members to nominate a name for the partnership.
* Simplified point 6: Failure by the taxable person to comply with any requirement imposed by or under the Act can result in the constituent members being treated as having failed severally.

* Simplified point 1: The regulations can provide for the continuation of a business when the person carrying it on dies, becomes incapacitated, or is subject to insolvency proceedings.
* Simplified point 2: The regulations can allow the person taking over the business to be treated as if they were the same person as the original business owner for a limited time.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can cover other matters the Commissioners think fit to ensure continuity in the application of the plastic packaging tax.
